channel.title: Excursion in Data Science (Posts about Bayesian)

item.title: Simple Bayesian Regression
item.dc:creator: Justin Dhooghe
item.description:
In [1]:
import pymc3 as pm
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from scipy.stats.mstats import mquantiles
In [2]:
#Create a fake data set with slope of 0.5 and y-intercept of 5 with random noise

NumberOfDataPoints = 10
x_data = np.linspace(0.0, 10., NumberOfDataPoints)
Noise = np.random.randn(NumberOfDataPoints)
y_True = 0.5*x_data + 5 + Noise

x_df = pd.DataFrame(data=x_data, columns = ['x'])
y_df = pd.DataFrame(data=y_True, columns = ['y'])
Data = pd.concat([x_df, y_df], axis = 1)
In [3]:
#Plot the points
plt.plot(x_data, y_True, marker = '.', linestyle='None')
plt.xlabel("x")
plt.ylabel("y")
Out[3]:
Text(0,0.5,'y')
In [4]:
with pm.Model() as RegressorModel:
    b = pm.Normal('Intercept', 0, sd=20) #y-intercept
    m = pm.Normal('Slope', 10., sd=10) #slope
    sigma = pm.Exponential('Sigma', 10., testval=1.) #noise
    likelihood = pm.Normal('y', mu = b + x_data * m, sd=sigma, observed=y_True)
In [5]:
with RegressorModel:
    trace = pm.sample(40000, cores=4)

Auto-assigning NUTS sampler...
Initializing NUTS using jitter+adapt_diag...
Multiprocess sampling (2 chains in 2 jobs)
NUTS: [Sigma_log__, Slope, Intercept]
100%|██████████| 40500/40500 [00:41<00:00, 980.70it/s]
The acceptance probability does not match the target. It is 0.879583853526, but should be close to 0.8. Try to increase the number of tuning steps.
The chain reached the maximum tree depth. Increase max_treedepth, increase target_accept or reparameterize.
In [6]:
plt.figure(figsize=(7, 7))
pm.traceplot(trace[100:])
plt.tight_layout()

<matplotlib.figure.Figure at 0x123943358>
In [8]:
SlopeTrace = trace['Slope'].T
InterceptTrace = trace['Intercept'].T
y = np.outer(x_data, SlopeTrace) + InterceptTrace
y_mean = np.mean(y, axis=1)
y_quant = mquantiles(y, [0.025, 0.975], axis = 1)
plt.plot(x_data, y_True, linestyle = 'None', marker = '.', label = 'Data')
plt.fill_between(x_data, y_quant[:, 0], y_quant[:, 1], alpha = 0.3, label = '97.5% Credible Interval')
plt.plot(x_data, y_mean, ls = '--', label='Mean Value')
plt.plot(x_data, 0.5*x_data+5., label='Real Value')
plt.ylabel("y")
plt.xlabel("x")
plt.legend()
Out[8]:
<matplotlib.legend.Legend at 0x120056a90>
